summary: Perform joint genotyping on one or more samples pre-called with HaplotypeCaller

arguments.summary: If true, adds a PG tag to created SAM/BAM/CRAM files.
arguments.name: --add-output-sam-program-record

arguments.summary: If true, adds a command line header line to created VCF files.
arguments.name: --add-output-vcf-command-line

arguments.summary: Margin of error in allele fraction to consider a somatic variant homoplasmic
arguments.name: --allele-fraction-error
arguments.fulltext: Margin of error in allele fraction to consider a somatic variant homoplasmic, i.e. if there is less than a 0.1% reference allele fraction, those reads are likely errors

arguments.summary: If provided, we will annotate records with the number of alternate alleles that were discovered (but not necessarily genotyped) at a given site
arguments.name: --annotate-with-num-discovered-alleles
arguments.fulltext:
Depending on the value of the --max_alternate_alleles argument, we may genotype only a fraction of the alleles being sent on for genotyping.
 Using this argument instructs the genotyper to annotate (in the INFO field) the number of alternate alleles that were originally discovered at the site.

arguments.summary: One or more specific annotations to add to variant calls
arguments.name: --annotation
arguments.fulltext: Which annotations to include in variant calls in the output. These supplement annotations provided by annotation groups.

arguments.summary: One or more groups of annotations to apply to variant calls
arguments.name: --annotation-group
arguments.fulltext:
Which groups of annotations to add to the output variant calls.
 Any requirements that are not met (e.g. failing to provide a pedigree file for a pedigree-based annotation) may cause the run to fail.

arguments.summary: One or more specific annotations to exclude from variant calls
arguments.name: --annotations-to-exclude
arguments.fulltext:
Which annotations to exclude from output in the variant calls.  Note that this argument has higher priority than the
 -A or -G arguments, so these annotations will be excluded even if they are explicitly included with the other
 options.

arguments.summary: read one or more arguments files and add them to the command line
arguments.name: --arguments_file

arguments.summary: Output called genotypes in final VCF (otherwise no-call)
arguments.name: --call-genotypes

arguments.summary: Size of the cloud-only prefetch buffer (in MB; 0 to disable). Defaults to cloudPrefetchBuffer if unset.
arguments.name: --cloud-index-prefetch-buffer

arguments.summary: Size of the cloud-only prefetch buffer (in MB; 0 to disable).
arguments.name: --cloud-prefetch-buffer

arguments.summary: If true, create a BAM/CRAM index when writing a coordinate-sorted BAM/CRAM file.
arguments.name: --create-output-bam-index

arguments.summary: If true, create a MD5 digest for any BAM/SAM/CRAM file created
arguments.name: --create-output-bam-md5

arguments.summary: If true, create a VCF index when writing a coordinate-sorted VCF file.
arguments.name: --create-output-variant-index

arguments.summary: If true, create a a MD5 digest any VCF file created.
arguments.name: --create-output-variant-md5

arguments.summary: dbSNP file
arguments.name: --dbsnp
arguments.fulltext: A dbSNP VCF file.

arguments.summary: If true, don't cache bam indexes, this will reduce memory requirements but may harm performance if many intervals are specified.  Caching is automatically disabled if there are no intervals specified.
arguments.name: --disable-bam-index-caching

arguments.summary: Read filters to be disabled before analysis
arguments.name: --disable-read-filter

arguments.summary: If specified, do not check the sequence dictionaries from our inputs for compatibility. Use at your own risk!
arguments.name: --disable-sequence-dictionary-validation

arguments.summary: Disable all tool default annotations
arguments.name: --disable-tool-default-annotations
arguments.fulltext: Hook allowing for the user to remove default annotations from the tool

arguments.summary: Disable all tool default read filters (WARNING: many tools will not function correctly without their default read filters on)
arguments.name: --disable-tool-default-read-filters

arguments.summary: Forfeit the use of the DRAGstr model to calculate genotype priors. This argument does not have any effect in the absence of DRAGstr model parameters (--dragstr-model-params)
arguments.name: --dont-use-dragstr-priors

arguments.summary: Use all possible annotations (not for the faint of heart)
arguments.name: --enable-all-annotations
arguments.fulltext:
You can use the -AX argument in combination with this one to exclude specific annotations. Note that some
 annotations may not be actually applied if they are not applicable to the data provided or if they are
 unavailable to the tool (e.g. there are several annotations that are currently not hooked up to
 HaplotypeCaller). At present no error or warning message will be provided, the annotation will simply be
 skipped silently. You can check the output VCF header to see which annotations were activated and thus might be applied (although
 this does not guarantee that the annotation was applied to all records in the VCF, since some annotations have
 additional requirements, e.g. minimum number of samples or heterozygous sites only -- see the documentation
 for individual annotations' requirements).

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals to exclude from processing
arguments.name: --exclude-intervals
arguments.fulltext:
Use this argument to exclude certain parts of the genome from the analysis (like -L, but the opposite).
 This argument can be specified multiple times. You can use samtools-style intervals either explicitly on the
 command line (e.g. -XL 1 or -XL 1:100-200) or by loading in a file containing a list of intervals
 (e.g. -XL myFile.intervals).

arguments.summary: sites at which to output genotypes even if non-variant in samples
arguments.name: --force-output-intervals

arguments.summary: Samples representing the population "founders"
arguments.name: --founder-id

arguments.summary: A configuration file to use with the GATK.
arguments.name: --gatk-config-file

arguments.summary: If the GCS bucket channel errors out, how many times it will attempt to re-initiate the connection
arguments.name: --gcs-max-retries

arguments.summary: Project to bill when accessing "requester pays" buckets. If unset, these buckets cannot be accessed.  User must have storage.buckets.get permission on the bucket being accessed.
arguments.name: --gcs-project-for-requester-pays

arguments.summary: Allow for optimizations to improve the usability and performance for shared Posix Filesystems(e.g. NFS, Lustre). If set, file level locking is disabled and file system writes are minimized.
arguments.name: --genomicsdb-shared-posixfs-optimizations

arguments.summary: Use BCF Codec Streaming for data from GenomicsDB instead of the default VCFCodec. BCFCodec performs slightly better but currently does not support 64-bit width positions and INFO fields and for computed annotation sizes to exceed 32-bit integer space.
arguments.name: --genomicsdb-use-bcf-codec
arguments.fulltext:
Currently there is no support for 64-bit fields in BCF2Codec. The VCFCodec allows for 64-bit
 width positions and INFO fields and for computed annotation sizes to exceed the 32-bit
 integer space while encoding/decoding with GenomicsDB. Use the BCF2Codec option if and
 only if performance is an issue.

arguments.summary: Use the GCS HDFS Connector instead of the native GCS SDK client with gs:// URLs.
arguments.name: --genomicsdb-use-gcs-hdfs-connector

arguments.summary: How we assign genotypes
arguments.name: --genotype-assignment-method

options.summary: set all of the genotype GT values to NO_CALL
options.name: SET_TO_NO_CALL

options.summary: Use the subsetted PLs to greedily assign genotypes
options.name: USE_PLS_TO_ASSIGN

options.summary: Use the existing, subsetted posteriors array to assign genotypes
options.name: USE_POSTERIORS_ANNOTATION

options.summary: set all of the genotype GT values to NO_CALL and remove annotations
options.name: SET_TO_NO_CALL_NO_ANNOTATIONS

options.summary:
Try to match the original GT calls, if at all possible

 Suppose I have 3 alleles: A/B/C and the following samples:

       original_GT best_match to A/B best_match to A/C
 S1 => A/A A/A A/A
 S2 => A/B A/B A/A
 S3 => B/B B/B A/A
 S4 => B/C A/B A/C
 S5 => C/C A/A C/C

 Basically, all alleles not in the subset map to ref.  It means that het-alt genotypes
 when split into 2 bi-allelic variants will be het in each, which is good in some cases,
 rather than the undetermined behavior when using the PLs to assign, which could result
 in hom-var or hom-ref for each, depending on the exact PL values.
options.name: BEST_MATCH_TO_ORIGINAL

options.summary: do not even bother changing the GTs
options.name: DO_NOT_ASSIGN_GENOTYPES

options.summary: Calculate posterior probabilities and use those to assign genotypes
options.name: USE_POSTERIOR_PROBABILITIES

options.summary: Use PLs unless they are unavailable, in which case use best match to original
options.name: PREFER_PLS

arguments.summary: display the help message
arguments.name: --help

arguments.summary: Heterozygosity value used to compute prior likelihoods for any locus.  See the GATKDocs for full details on the meaning of this population genetics concept
arguments.name: --heterozygosity
arguments.fulltext:
The expected heterozygosity value used to compute prior probability that a locus is non-reference.

 The default priors are for provided for humans:

 het = 1e-3

 which means that the probability of N samples being hom-ref at a site is:

 1 - sum_i_2N (het / i)

 Note that heterozygosity as used here is the population genetics concept:

 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zygosity#Heterozygosity_in_population_genetics

 That is, a hets value of 0.01 implies that two randomly chosen chromosomes from the population of organisms
 would differ from each other (one being A and the other B) at a rate of 1 in 100 bp.

 Note that this quantity has nothing to do with the likelihood of any given sample having a heterozygous genotype,
 which in the GATK is purely determined by the probability of the observed data P(D | AB) under the model that there
 may be a AB het genotype.  The posterior probability of this AB genotype would use the het prior, but the GATK
 only uses this posterior probability in determining the prob. that a site is polymorphic.  So changing the
 het parameters only increases the chance that a site will be called non-reference across all samples, but
 doesn't actually change the output genotype likelihoods at all, as these aren't posterior probabilities at all.

 The quantity that changes whether the GATK considers the possibility of a het genotype at all is the ploidy,
 which determines how many chromosomes each individual in the species carries.

arguments.summary: Standard deviation of heterozygosity for SNP and indel calling.
arguments.name: --heterozygosity-stdev
arguments.fulltext:
The standard deviation of the distribution of alt allele fractions.  The above heterozygosity parameters give the
 *mean* of this distribution; this parameter gives its spread.

arguments.summary: Include loci found to be non-variant after genotyping
arguments.name: --include-non-variant-sites

arguments.summary: Heterozygosity for indel calling.  See the GATKDocs for heterozygosity for full details on the meaning of this population genetics concept
arguments.name: --indel-heterozygosity
arguments.fulltext: This argument informs the prior probability of having an indel at a site.

arguments.summary: BAM/SAM/CRAM file containing reads
arguments.name: --input

arguments.summary: Finalize input GVCF according to somatic (i.e. Mutect2) TLODs (BETA feature)
arguments.name: --input-is-somatic
arguments.fulltext:
"Genotype" somatic GVCFs, outputting genotypes according to confidently called alt alleles, which may lead to inconsistent ploidy
 Note that the Mutect2 reference confidence mode is in BETA -- the likelihoods model and output format are subject to change in subsequent versions.

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are excluding.
arguments.name: --interval-exclusion-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -XL. For example, '-XL 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-XL 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Interval merging rule for abutting intervals
arguments.name: --interval-merging-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program merges abutting intervals (i.e. intervals that are directly side-by-side but do not
 actually overlap) into a single continuous interval. However you can change this behavior if you want them to be
 treated as separate intervals instead.

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are including.
arguments.name: --interval-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -L. For example, '-L 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-L 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Set merging approach to use for combining interval inputs
arguments.name: --interval-set-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program will take the UNION of all intervals specified using -L and/or -XL. However, you can
 change this setting for -L, for example if you want to take the INTERSECTION of the sets instead. E.g. to
 perform the analysis only on chromosome 1 exomes, you could specify -L exomes.intervals -L 1 --interval-set-rule
 INTERSECTION. However, it is not possible to modify the merging approach for intervals passed using -XL (they will
 always be merged using UNION).

 Note that if you specify both -L and -XL, the -XL interval set will be subtracted from the -L interval set.

options.summary: Take the union of all intervals
options.name: UNION

options.summary: Take the intersection of intervals (the subset that overlaps all intervals specified)
options.name: INTERSECTION

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals over which to operate
arguments.name: --intervals

arguments.summary: If specified, keep the combined raw annotations
arguments.name: --keep-combined-raw-annotations
arguments.fulltext: If specified, keep the combined raw annotations (e.g. AS_SB_TABLE) after genotyping.  This is applicable to Allele-Specific annotations

arguments.summary: Lenient processing of VCF files
arguments.name: --lenient

arguments.summary: Maximum number of alternate alleles to genotype
arguments.name: --max-alternate-alleles
arguments.fulltext:
If there are more than this number of alternate alleles presented to the genotyper (either through discovery or GENOTYPE_GIVEN ALLELES),
 then only this many alleles will be used.  Note that genotyping sites with many alternate alleles is both CPU and memory intensive and it
 scales exponentially based on the number of alternate alleles.  Unless there is a good reason to change the default value, we highly recommend
 that you not play around with this parameter.

 See also {@link #MAX_GENOTYPE_COUNT}.

arguments.summary: Maximum number of genotypes to consider at any site
arguments.name: --max-genotype-count
arguments.fulltext:
If there are more than this number of genotypes at a locus presented to the genotyper, then only this many genotypes will be used.
 The possible genotypes are simply different ways of partitioning alleles given a specific ploidy asumption.
 Therefore, we remove genotypes from consideration by removing alternate alleles that are the least well supported.
 The estimate of allele support is based on the ranking of the candidate haplotypes coming out of the graph building step.
 Note that the reference allele is always kept.

 Note that genotyping sites with large genotype counts is both CPU and memory intensive.
 Unless there is a good reason to change the default value, we highly recommend that you not play around with this parameter.

 The maximum number of alternative alleles used in the genotyping step will be the lesser of the two:
 1. the largest number of alt alleles, given ploidy, that yields a genotype count no higher than {@link #MAX_GENOTYPE_COUNT}
 2. the value of {@link #MAX_ALTERNATE_ALLELES}

 See also {@link #MAX_ALTERNATE_ALLELES}.

arguments.summary: If non-zero, partitions VCF output into shards, each containing up to the given number of records.
arguments.name: --max-variants-per-shard

arguments.summary: Boolean flag to import all data in between intervals.
arguments.name: --merge-input-intervals
arguments.fulltext:
Import all data between specified intervals.   Improves performance using large lists of intervals, as in exome
 sequencing, especially if GVCF data only exists for specified intervals.  Use with
 --only-output-calls-starting-in-intervals if input GVCFs contain calls outside the specified intervals.

arguments.summary: Number of hom-ref genotypes to infer at sites not present in a panel
arguments.name: --num-reference-samples-if-no-call
arguments.fulltext:
When a variant is not seen in any panel, this argument controls whether to infer (and with what effective strength)
 that only reference alleles were observed at that site. E.g. "If not seen in 1000Genomes, treat it as AC=0,
 AN=2000".

arguments.summary: Restrict variant output to sites that start within provided intervals
arguments.name: --only-output-calls-starting-in-intervals
arguments.fulltext: This option can only be activated if intervals are specified.

arguments.summary: File to which variants should be written
arguments.name: --output

arguments.summary: Pedigree file for determining the population "founders"
arguments.name: --pedigree

arguments.summary: Callset to use in calculating genotype priors
arguments.name: --population-callset
arguments.fulltext:
Supporting external panel. Allele counts from this panel (taken from AC,AN or MLEAC,AN or raw genotypes) will
 be used to inform the frequency distribution underlying the genotype priors. These files must be VCF 4.2 spec or later.
 Note that unlike CalculateGenotypePosteriors, HaplotypeCaller only allows one supporting callset.

arguments.summary: Whether to suppress job-summary info on System.err.
arguments.name: --QUIET

arguments.summary: Read filters to be applied before analysis
arguments.name: --read-filter

arguments.summary: Indices to use for the read inputs. If specified, an index must be provided for every read input and in the same order as the read inputs. If this argument is not specified, the path to the index for each input will be inferred automatically.
arguments.name: --read-index

arguments.summary: Validation stringency for all SAM/BAM/CRAM/SRA files read by this program.  The default stringency value SILENT can improve performance when processing a BAM file in which variable-length data (read, qualities, tags) do not otherwise need to be decoded.
arguments.name: --read-validation-stringency

arguments.summary: Reference sequence file
arguments.name: --reference

arguments.summary: Ploidy (number of chromosomes) per sample. For pooled data, set to (Number of samples in each pool * Sample Ploidy).
arguments.name: --sample-ploidy
arguments.fulltext: Sample ploidy - equivalent to number of chromosomes per pool. In pooled experiments this should be = # of samples in pool * individual sample ploidy

arguments.summary: Output traversal statistics every time this many seconds elapse
arguments.name: --seconds-between-progress-updates

arguments.summary: Use the given sequence dictionary as the master/canonical sequence dictionary.  Must be a .dict file.
arguments.name: --sequence-dictionary

arguments.summary: display hidden arguments
arguments.name: --showHidden

arguments.summary: If true, don't emit genotype fields when writing vcf file output.
arguments.name: --sites-only-vcf-output

arguments.summary: The minimum phred-scaled confidence threshold at which variants should be called
arguments.name: --standard-min-confidence-threshold-for-calling
arguments.fulltext:
The minimum phred-scaled confidence threshold at which variants should be called. Only variant sites with QUAL equal
 or greater than this threshold will be called. Note that since version 3.7, we no longer differentiate high confidence
 from low confidence calls at the calling step. The default call confidence threshold is set low intentionally to achieve
 high sensitivity, which will allow false positive calls as a side effect. Be sure to perform some kind of filtering after
 calling to reduce the amount of false positives in your final callset. Note that when HaplotypeCaller is used in GVCF mode
 (using either -ERC GVCF or -ERC BP_RESOLUTION) the call threshold is automatically set to zero. Call confidence thresholding
 will then be performed in the subsequent GenotypeGVCFs command.

 Note that the default was changed from 10.0 to 30.0 in version 4.1.0.0 to accompany the switch to use the the new quality score by default.

arguments.summary: Temp directory to use.
arguments.name: --tmp-dir

arguments.summary: LOD threshold to emit variant to VCF.
arguments.name: --tumor-lod-to-emit
arguments.fulltext:
Only variants with tumor LODs exceeding this threshold will be written to the VCF, regardless of filter status.
 Set to less than or equal to tumor_lod. Increase argument value to reduce false positives in the callset.

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkDeflater (as opposed to IntelDeflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-deflater

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkInflater (as opposed to IntelInflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-inflater

arguments.summary: Use the new AF model instead of the so-called exact model
arguments.name: --use-new-qual-calculator
arguments.fulltext: As of version 4.1.0.0, this argument is no longer needed because the new qual score is now on by default. See GATK 3.3 release notes for more details.

arguments.summary: if available, use the genotype posterior probabilities to calculate the site QUAL
arguments.name: --use-posteriors-to-calculate-qual

arguments.summary: A VCF file containing variants
arguments.name: --variant

arguments.summary: Control verbosity of logging.
arguments.name: --verbosity

arguments.summary: display the version number for this tool
arguments.name: --version

description:
Perform joint genotyping on one or more samples pre-called with HaplotypeCaller

This tool is designed to perform joint genotyping on a single input, which may contain one or many samples. In any case, the input samples must possess genotype likelihoods produced by HaplotypeCaller with `-ERC GVCF` or `-ERC BP_RESOLUTION`.

Input

The GATK4 GenotypeGVCFs tool can take only one input track. Options are 1) a single single-sample GVCF 2) a single multi-sample GVCF created by CombineGVCFs or 3) a GenomicsDB workspace created by GenomicsDBImport. A sample-level GVCF is produced by HaplotypeCaller with the `-ERC GVCF` setting.

Output

A final VCF in which all samples have been jointly genotyped.

Usage example

Perform joint genotyping on a singular sample by providing a single-sample GVCF or on a cohort by providing a combined multi-sample GVCF

 gatk --java-options "-Xmx4g" GenotypeGVCFs \
   -R Homo_sapiens_assembly38.fasta \
   -V input.g.vcf.gz \
   -O output.vcf.gz

Perform joint genotyping on GenomicsDB workspace created with GenomicsDBImport

 gatk --java-options "-Xmx4g" GenotypeGVCFs \
   -R Homo_sapiens_assembly38.fasta \
   -V gendb://my_database \
   -O output.vcf.gz \
   --tmp-dir /path/to/large/tmp

Caveats

  • Only GVCF files produced by HaplotypeCaller (or CombineGVCFs) can be used as input for this tool. Some other programs produce files that they call GVCFs but those lack some important information (accurate genotype likelihoods for every position) that GenotypeGVCFs requires for its operation.
  • Cannot take multiple GVCF files in one command.
  • The amount of temporary disk storage required by GenomicsDBImport may exceed what is available in the default location: `/tmp`. The command line argument `--tmp-dir` can be used to specify an alternate temperary storage location with sufficient space.

Special note on ploidy

This tool is able to handle any ploidy (or mix of ploidies) intelligently; there is no need to specify ploidy for non-diploid organisms.
name: GenotypeGVCFs
